Sullivan | Rivalry game about pride, postseason

Louisville looking for Orange Bowl berth; Kentucky eager to return to bowl.

Sullivan | Rivalry game about pride, postseason

Tim Sullivan, tsullivan@courier-journal.com 2:56 p.m. EST November 27, 2014

Sep 27, 2014; Louisville, KY, USA; Louisville Cardinals defensive end Lorenzo Mauldin (94) celebrates after sacking Wake Forest Demon Deacons quarterback John Wolford (not pictured) during the second quarter at Papa John's Cardinal Stadium. Louisville defeated Wake Forest 20-10. Mandatory Credit: Jamie Rhodes-USA TODAY Sports(Photo: Jamie Rhodes / Jamie Rhodes-USA TODAY Sports)

6 CONNECT 15 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

Rivalry games are worth the wait. They belong at the end of the football season, as punctuation rather than preface, when the stakes are highest and the schedule allows no more opportunities for atonement.

Granted, the college football calendar gets a little crowded in late November. To the unaffiliated fan, Saturday's Kentucky-Louisville Governor's Cup game is likely to be overshadowed by the Iron Bowl (Alabama-Auburn), the Egg Bowl (Mississippi-Mississippi State), the Civil War (Oregon-Oregon State) and the annual gridiron grudgefest between Ohio State and Michigan.

Yet as backyard scraps go, this particular UK-U of L game resonates more than most. Beyond the familiar friction of intersecting fan bases with the shared goal of gloating at the final gun, the 27th Kentucky-Louisville game carries significant consequences for both sides.

Despite five straight defeats, the wobbly Wildcats continue to cling to a chance to earn bowl-eligibility with a sixth victory. Beyond the intrinsic rewards beating Louisville would bring, that's an alluring incentive.

Louisville, meanwhile, fresh from its euphoric victory at Notre Dame, remains in resume-building mode as the bowls consider potential matchups. The Cardinals know additional achievements can mean a higher place in the polls and, should things break right, an opportunity to take their talents to South Beach.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Kentucky's bowl hopes hinge on defeating Louisville in rivalry game

Representatives of the Orange Bowl, Russell Athletic Bowl and Independence Bowl are expected to attend Saturday's game.

Media bowl projections have also placed Louisville in El Paso's Sun Bowl (SI.com and ESPN's Mark Schlabach), Jacksonville's Gator Bowl (Yahoo! and ESPN's Brett McMurphy) and Nashville's Music City Bowl (CBSSports.com and Fox Sports).

"Typically I would be there for this game," Music City Bowl President Scott Ramsey said. "We've got a lot of interest in Louisville. But simply, it's Thanksgiving weekend, and I had an opportunity to get away with the family, and I took it."

EX-U OF L PLAYERS: Former Cards say UK rivalry is intense, heated

RELATED: Can Kentucky corral U of L's DeVante Parker?

Perfectly understandable. While the Kentucky-Louisville basketball game is a circle-the-date happening, an annual event played between neighboring programs of championship caliber and obsessive fans, the football rivalry is conducted in a comparatively minor key. Since the UK-U of L series resumed in 1994 (following a 70-year hiatus), the two schools have recorded winning records in the same season only three times. In each of those cases (1998, 2002 and 2006), the Governor's Cup was played as a season opener.

Kentucky quarterback Patrick Towles scrambles for some yards during the first half of an NCAA college football game against Georgia at Commonwealth Stadium in Lexington, Ky., Saturday, Nov. 8, 2014. Georgia beat Kentucky 63-31. (AP Photo/David Stephenson)(Photo: David Stephenson / AP)

Given that modest foundation, building the game into something that transcends state boundaries figures to be a long-term proposition.

Though Bobby Petrino's return has reinvigorated Louisville's fan base and the recruiting successes of Mark Stoops have buoyed Big Blue Nation, their competition is unlikely to move the national needle until the two teams are seen, simultaneously, as elite.

"We're trying to create it to be a bigger and better rivalry," Stoops said. "I think that comes from us having to play better football and winning more games and putting ourselves in a position where we can get this game on a more national scale. But it's important. It's important to the people in this state. It's important to our fans and our players and coaches."

The game is of sufficient importance to Patrick Towles that the UK quarterback abandoned his protective red jersey in practice this week rather than be seen in Louisville colors. Running back Brandon Radcliff said U of L is approaching the game "like Kentucky is our bowl game right here."

COURIER-JOURNAL

Kentucky coaches ramp up rivalry's importance

Though Louisville linebacker Lorenzo Mauldin says, "We know Coach Petrino doesn't like Kentucky," the Cardinals' coach has been careful to maintain a diplomatic tone in his public utterances. Though he was 4-0 against UK in his previous tour at Louisville, and ignored in the hiring process when Kentucky hired Stoops, Petrino is playing down the possibility of schadenfreude, of deriving pleasure from preventing UK from reaching a bowl game.

"I don't think it's about that at all." he said "It's just all about ourselves. We just want to get to nine wins, have the opportunity to go to the best bowl game we can. You really don't worry about what's in front of Kentucky. It's really about us and what we want to accomplish and how we want to go out and play."

GOVERNOR'S CUP: A Kentucky-Louisville primer

FUTURE STARS: Many key recruits to visit U of L for UK game

That shows a lot of restraint for a rivalry game. When Georgia Tech plays Georgia, the traditional theme is, "Clean, old-fashioned hate."

When Ohio State meets Michigan, someone is sure to invoke Woody Hayes' 1968 decision to order a two-point conversion following the last touchdown of the Buckeyes' 50-14 blowout.

Asked why he had he gone for two, Hayes captured the essence of rivalry games in a clause.

"Because," he said, "I couldn't go for three."

Tim Sullivan can be reached at (502) 582-4650, by email at tsullivan@courier-journal.com, and on Twitter @TimSullivan714
